Hi,

The large variation inteh distribution of genomes among species is 
something that is expected if the fitness of the species also varies a 
lot - the fittest species will be the largest in size. So mayeb this is 
actually normal, it depends on the relative fitness of your species.

The complexity of the population will rise steadily and will therefore 
normally require the threshold to rise steadily also to keep the number 
of species constant. If the number of species is continually to high 
then this indicates that the threshold isn;t able to rise fast enough. 
First though I would recommend starting your experiment with a higher 
initial threshold, that way the threshold won't be playing catch-up 
right from the start. If later on the # of species starts to rise again 
then you probably need to increase the delta from 0.3.

In SharpNEAT I use a delta of 0.1, but this then starts to increase if 
the number of species does not fall within defined limits. Think of this 
as accelerating the change in threshold. This can have the effect of 
overshooting the ideal value if the threshold was way out to start with, 
but this shouldn't happen if the initial value is set correctly.


Colin.
